question_details.title: Will Threads report more monthly active users than Twitter before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2023-07-23 14:51:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/17763). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

Mark Zuckerberg launched a twitter competitor, Threads, on July 5, 2023. On the first day after launch, Zuckerberg [claimed](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-07-06/millions-sign-up-to-meta-twitter-rival-app-threads-in-hours/102572568) 30 million users signed up, and after the first week, [100 million had](https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/19/tech/threads-meta-growth-plan/index.html), though it is hard to estimate how many of those users will be "monthly active" until some months pass. Many of these users were able to sign up with just one or two clicks from Instagram. 

As of December 2022, Twitter had [368M monthly active users](https://www.statista.com/statistics/303681/twitter-users-worldwide/), and many expect this to fall due to erratic leadership from Elon Musk. Meta's other properties, Facebook, Instagram, and Whatsapp, are all well over 1B MAUs.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":17763,"question_id":17763}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **YES** if, before Dec 31, 2025, Meta publicly reports Threads has a Monthly Active User number higher than the best public estimates of Twitter's MAUs at that time, and **NO** otherwise.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Meta reacts to historic FTC antitrust case victory**
Meta celebrated a major legal victory over the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) on November 18, 2025, after U.S. District Judge James Boasberg rejected the FTC’s attempt to force Meta to divest Instagram and WhatsApp. The court ruled that the FTC failed to prove Meta retains monopoly power in social networking, citing the rapidly evolving digital landscape. Judge Boasberg noted that the 'river' of social networking has fundamentally changed since the 2020 lawsuit was filed, with new competitors like TikTok, YouTube, Snapchat, and Apple’s messaging services now playing central roles. Meta’s spokesperson, via Andy Stone on X, stated, 'The Court's decision today recognizes that Meta faces fierce competition. Our products are beneficial for people and businesses and exemplify American innovation and economic growth.' The FTC had argued that Meta’s acquisitions of Instagram (2012) and WhatsApp (2014) were strategic moves to eliminate competition, citing internal emails showing CEO Mark Zuckerberg’s 'better to buy than compete' philosophy. Meta countered that both platforms were small at the time and that the acquisitions helped scale them into global services. Zuckerberg testified that the early emails reflected exploratory thinking, not a plan to suppress rivals. The ruling marks a significant setback for the FTC, which recently won major antitrust cases against Google. While the FTC may appeal, Meta’s leadership emphasized its focus on innovation and competition in a dynamic digital marketplace.

**Meta scores a win after judge rules the social media giant is not an illegal monopoly**
On November 18, 2025, U.S. Federal Judge James Boasberg ruled that Meta is not a monopoly in the social networking market, rejecting a 2020 antitrust lawsuit filed by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC). The FTC had argued that Meta violated antitrust laws by acquiring Instagram and WhatsApp to eliminate competition. The judge concluded that platforms like TikTok and YouTube serve as effective competitors, preventing Meta from monopolizing the market. He also noted that the social media landscape has evolved significantly since the lawsuit was filed, particularly due to the rise of AI-generated content, which weakened the FTC’s case. The ruling is a major victory for Meta, which relies heavily on Instagram for ad revenue and WhatsApp for international reach and business subscriptions. Although Meta has 3.3 billion daily users, CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified during the seven-week trial that Facebook’s popularity is declining. The decision also represents a significant win for Silicon Valley amid increasing regulatory scrutiny of Big Tech, as Google was recently found to be a monopoly in two separate cases, and Apple and Amazon face ongoing antitrust litigation. CNN has reached out to Meta and the FTC for comment, and the story is developing.

**Meta scores a win after judge rules the social media giant is not an illegal monopoly | CNN Business**
On November 18, 2025, federal judge James Boasberg ruled that Meta is not a monopoly in the social networking market, delivering a major legal victory for the company after the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) sued in 2020 to force Meta to divest Instagram and WhatsApp. The FTC argued that Meta violated antitrust laws by acquiring potential rivals to eliminate competition. During a seven-week trial, Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified that platforms like YouTube and TikTok provide strong competition. Judge Boasberg agreed, stating that TikTok and YouTube prevent Meta from monopolizing the market, and noted that Meta’s share of time spent on social media platforms is modest and declining. He emphasized that even if YouTube were excluded from the market, Meta would still not hold a monopoly. The judge also highlighted that the social media landscape has evolved significantly since the FTC filed its case, particularly due to the rise of AI-generated content, which weakened the agency’s original arguments. The decision is a significant win for Silicon Valley, as other tech giants like Google, Apple, and Amazon face ongoing antitrust litigation. **Meta's Patent Focus on Search and Data Management Sets It Apart from Google**
Meta, originally founded as Facebook, has rapidly shifted its focus from a social networking platform to a leading metaverse developer. Despite being the youngest company among GAFAM, Meta holds significant societal influence, with its platforms—Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp—reaching 3.74 billion monthly active users by December 2022. The company's pivot to the metaverse began with the 2014 acquisition of Oculus VR and culminated in a corporate rebranding to 'Meta' in 2021. A key driver behind its strategic shift was the 2016 Cambridge Analytica scandal, where personal data from Facebook was misused in U.S. presidential elections, prompting global regulatory scrutiny of tech platforms. Analysis of patents from 2001 to 2024—based on a random sample of 30,000 GAFAM patents—reveals that Meta holds approximately 6% of the total, highlighting its strong focus on search and data management technologies, distinguishing it from competitors like Google. This patent profile underscores Meta’s emphasis on user analytics and digital infrastructure, setting it apart in the tech landscape.

**Meta Wins Federal Trade Commission Antitrust Lawsuit Over WhatsApp and Instagram Acquisitions**
Meta won a high-profile antitrust lawsuit against the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC), with U.S. District Court Judge James Boasberg issuing a memorandum opinion on Tuesday stating that the FTC failed to prove its claims. The case, originally filed five years ago, centered on Meta’s acquisitions of Instagram in 2012 for $1 billion and WhatsApp in 2014 for $19 billion. Judge Boasberg ruled that the FTC must demonstrate Meta currently holds monopoly power, not just past dominance, and concluded it failed to do so. In 2021, Boasberg had initially dismissed the case for insufficient evidence of Facebook’s market power; the FTC later filed an amended complaint with additional data on user numbers and competitive metrics. In 2022, he allowed the case to proceed due to the enhanced detail. Key Meta figures—including CEO Mark Zuckerberg, former COO Sheryl Sandberg, Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom, and other current and former executives—testified during the trial, which began in April 2025. The FTC had argued that the acquisitions should have been blocked and demanded the divestiture of Instagram and WhatsApp, claiming no viable alternatives exist to Facebook and Instagram for social communication. However, Judge Boasberg emphasized that the FTC must prove current anticompetitive behavior, not past actions, noting that social media’s core use and content formats have changed significantly since Meta’s early days. He found that TikTok and YouTube are now seen as genuine substitutes for Meta’s platforms, with strong economic competition evidenced by user migration, Meta’s massive investments to remain competitive, and internal industry documents identifying Meta as a key rival. Boasberg concluded: 'Meta is not an unchallenged monopolist,' and the evidence supporting Meta’s competitive position was 'credible and persuasive.' This ruling follows a similar outcome in October 2025, when Google avoided forced divestiture despite being found to have monopolized the search market, though it was ordered to loosen control over search data.

**US: Meta wins huge antitrust case, avoids break-up**
On November 18, 2025, US District Judge James Boasberg ruled in favor of Meta in a landmark antitrust case brought by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) in 2020, preventing the company from being forced to divest Instagram and WhatsApp. The FTC had alleged that Meta acquired these platforms to eliminate competition, citing Mark Zuckerberg’s 2008 maxim, 'It's better to buy than compete.' Judge Boasberg concluded that the FTC failed to prove Meta currently holds monopoly power, stating that the market landscape has changed significantly: 'the wall' between social networking and social media has broken down. He emphasized that Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube now offer nearly identical features, particularly short-form video content via Reels, with only 7% of Instagram users now engaging primarily with friends' content.
